file_content.text: Happy to help.
While you were fighting out there, I could feel it.
Your energy, your heartbeat. Your injuries.
It's not unusual between a Master and Padawan, and we're... closer than most.
We do share a bond.
I read about that. I never thought I'd feel it.
That must have been upsetting.
Are you alright?
It was... weird. Until you won, anyway.
I'm not shy about protecting myself, especially if you're feeling what I feel.
Don't worry about me.
Oh. Very confident.
I've never been so close to anyone in my life. This feeling... there aren't words for it.
There are, but they're usually saved for wedding ceremonies.
Marry me.
Wait. What are you saying?
I'm saying that I love you, Nadia. Will you be my wife?
I want to marry you.
Yes. Yes, I will! Oh, I love you!
Us, together as husband and wife, for the rest of our lives. How does that sound?
Let me propose more clearly.
It... it sounds wonderful! I never thought--come here!
Listen, listen. For us--for my people--marriage isn't... it's not just a ritual. It's something that changes, and grows.
First, we make a promise. "All seasons, all worlds. Under stars, and earth. You, and I."
All seasons, all worlds. Under... stars, and earth. You, and I, Nadia.
Let me promise that, too.
I never thought anyone would say those words to me.
You deserve a beautiful wedding.
We should have a ceremony.
I'd need ages to plan it all out! But yes... somewhere peaceful. Away from any fighting.
An oath can be broken, but what we have goes beyond words.
We don't need promises.
I love you.
I know this is just the beginning for us.
Poor choice of words. I apologize.
I meant nothing by it.
You really, really need to think before you speak.
So the lines you quoted to me aren't enough anymore.
No more poems, then?
That's just a story. This is real.
Feelings like that are meant to be enjoyed, not explained away.
Words aren't necessary.
I'm changing, I can feel it. And it's because of you. I never want to let you go.
Like I was sharing your weapon. And your injuries. But I was still myself too.
Sometimes, a Master and Padawan build up such a strong rapport, the Force flows through them as one.
A Force bond.
I read about them. But actually experiencing one...
Experiencing a Force bond like that is often a shock. The fact you sensed it, and stayed in control, shows you've come far.
This is a big step for you.
Don't concern yourself.
Is it going to happen a lot?
It wasn't a bad feeling. Just odd, being connected to the Force on two levels. It might be fun to feel it again.
I've been thinking about home. The training's helped me be honest with myself.
I'm not going back. I'll be their representative, but too much has happened for me to just settle there again. And I'm happy about that.
Wherever you are, that's home to me. Whatever happens, I want to be with you, always.
There's nothing I'd like more.
That sounds perfect.
So it's settled.
Are you sure? I'd hate for you to regret this later.
That's a big decision.
This is the right thing to do, for me and for us.
The galaxy can be a cruel place, especially to those who care for each other.
It may be a difficult journey.
I'm not afraid.
You've given me a new life. All I want is to see the next horizon, and keep learning. With you.
With that attitude, you might find yourself on the Council some day. Or going even further.
You'll be a great Jedi.
And you'll get a paragraph or two in my biography.
Every teacher should be blessed with such a student.
You do me honor.
I knew I'd made the right choice.
I'll remember that next time you say I'm working you too hard.
[Tease] So no more complaints.
Ack. Next time I'll think my wording through.
Come on! Time's wasting, and there's so much to do.
Listen to this.
On broken feet I walk, crushed and alone. / The lies they told me have turned the world gray.
But oh, that you still breathe and live / Is a song in this void, that gives me life again.
I didn't know you wrote poetry.
Something of yours?
No, it's not mine.
I like it. Where are the lines from?
Pretty, but unfamiliar.
It's from "Kalas and Fiana," one of our romances. I've always loved it, but you've helped me understand it.
I'd rather listen to you than to a poet talking about someone I've never met.
Talk to me, don't quote.
It just reminds me of you.
There's been so much death. But there's life here, too; you've shown me what you fight for. What you live for.
I love you.
I've loved you for a long time.
And I, you.
I know.
I was beginning to think you'd never say it.
At last.
Ha. Hope it was worth the wait.
Few Jedi are so honest, especially after hearing the Council's warnings.
You're not afraid of love?
I won't live in fear of... of something that might happen, someday. I love you. That's here, and now.
I told you I needed time. But now I'm ready to be with you.
I didn't want you to be anything but certain.
I'm glad you're sure.
Oh, just kiss me.
I wasn't sure I could be patient much longer.
It hasn't been an easy wait...
Follow me.
Let's make the most of the time before we're disturbed.
Then come with me.
I love how you think.
I want you to know something.
Whatever happens, you're not alone. I'll always be here for you.
You've proven yourself time and again.
You already have been.
We don't need to speak, you and I.
This was greater than words.
Then I'll save that poem's ending for another time.
There's no need to promise anything to me.
I'm just happy to have you.
But saying something makes it real. You have my word. As well as my heart.
A woman back home asked me for advice. From what she says, it sounds like her little boy is Force sensitive.
She's asking what she should do for him. But I don't know what to tell her! She seems to think I know everything!
Knowledge is boundless, but comprehension is not.
Ah, who can know everything?
Ugh. Am I going to start talking like this one day?
It would be best if the boy was sent to Tython. He'll be accepted there.
Her son should be trained.
I suppose. I wouldn't want him to grow up like I did.
I'll write back to her. And to Master Satele, so she can expect a new arrival.
You'd be surprised how many people believe we have all the answers.
People expect that of Jedi.
No wonder you look so stressed sometimes.
Okay, okay. I'll tell her I'm meditating on it. I'll come up with something.
How do you think my training's going?
Jedi training can only be judged over years, but you've made a very promising start.
You've begun well.
I can't say. Offering congratulations just inflates a student's ego.
Sorry, praise is bad for you.
Aha! So I'm doing okay?
I thought so. I feel different. More myself.
Your combat technique is still sloppy; your control and focus still need a lot of work...
There's room for improvement.
I know, I can always do better. But even a little bit of study has been good for me.
I've got a level of control I never had before. It's great! I want to keep going!
Tython's not at all like I imagined.
It was even more beautiful! Peaceful, but wild too.
I could sense something there. Like the first Jedi who broke with the order left some of that darkness behind.
Tell me what you've learned from going to Tython.
What has this taught you?
I don't know. I talked to other Padawans--I'm much further along than some of them. They even asked me questions!
Tython is strong in the Force, and like the Force, it has both darkness and light. Not everyone can feel it.
You sensed that? Impressive.
Actually, Tython's a lot like home. I wonder what I'd sense now, if I went back there.
It's like Tython's a place where... where my powers and the Jedi teachings meet. Even if I wasn't your Padawan, there's somewhere I'd belong.
Thank you for letting me go there. I'll never forget it.
You've had your little field trip. Time to get back to work.
I hope we can move on now.
Yes, master. Whatever you say.
I got word from home about the spaceport. Remember? They wanted to demolish the Annex ruins, and build it there?
There was some grumbling but I think everyone's settled down now. I can't believe they really listened to me.
I feel like a diplomat now. But all this training... I still don't feel like a Jedi.
Negotiation and problem-solving skills are vital. You can't fix everything with a lightsaber.
Jedi are diplomats, too.
I know. But it's more than that.
You're gifted, but Jedi training is a lifetime's pursuit.
It takes time, Nadia.
It's not about where I'm going, it's where I started.
We're hardly in a typical situation for Padawan training, but I'm doing my best.
So my teaching's to blame?
Oh no! I didn't mean that at all!
I want to walk the same path you did. Go to Tython. See the Jedi Temple. Follow where the ancient Jedi went.
I wouldn't be gone long--long enough to explore, of course! I have all your maps from the ship's computer. I'm ready.
A sojourn on Tython would be good for you.
Yes, I think you are.
If you go to Tython with a clear purpose, you'll get much more out of your time there.
Let me give you a task.
Sure! What do you want me to do?
There's a settlement on Tython called Kallikori Village. The people there are poor and often hungry. They could use your help.
Help the Twi'lek villagers.
Absolutely, I'll see what I can do for them.
Go out into the wilds, use what tools you can find, and create something useful. Anything you wish.
Make an item by hand.
What does that have to do with Jedi training?
No culture survives without engineers and farmers. The Jedi are no exception.
We need practical skills.
I suppose we can't live on the Force.
We serve the people of the Republic. They need food, medicine, and fuel more than the Force.
Because it could help others.
I see. I didn't mean to sound selfish.
You never know when you'll lose your lightsaber, even your connection to the Force, and need to improvise.
In case you stop being a Jedi.
That can happen? I had no idea!
All right, I'll see what I can make. It'll be fun--see you soon!
Focus on the ruins, help the excavators; search for anything the order might be able to use.
Look for artifacts.
Okay. Your notes said those ruins were full of droids and monsters, I should be extra careful.
We have a lot on our hands, Nadia, you can't just disappear.
You're needed here.
But I thought you wanted me to learn. To become a true Jedi. Please? It'd mean so much to me.
Very well. Anything for some peace and quiet.
Okay, I give in!
Tython is full of predators and Flesh Raiders. If you go, I want you back in one piece.
As long as you're careful.
Me too! It's okay, I'm armed and I've got your notes to keep me safe.
Don't be gone long, and be sure you don't get sidetracked on the way back.
In that case, you can go.
Oh, thank you, thank you! I'll get my things right away!
You're the best! I mean--I appreciate your great kindness, master. See you soon!
Can we talk?
I didn't mean to... pressure you, before. I wasn't thinking. I never think.
I care about you, I do. But you must think I'm... oh, I don't know.
There's nothing to apologize for.
It's alright, Nadia.
You're a beautiful, sweet, gifted woman, and nothing will convince me otherwise.
I think you're amazing.
Oh. Oh, good.
I was scared you'd think less of me. I should have known better.
I took your advances in the spirit they were given.
Actually, I was flattered.
I thought I'd made a fool of myself.
I know the galaxy's dangerous. But if you rush, you miss out on everything worth surviving for.
Your training appears to be paying off already.
That was rather insightful.
I'm learning about all kinds of things.
Quite right. Some things should never be rushed.
Exactly.
I won't forget. Just give me time.
Barely into her studies, and she's already preaching to her Master.
So wise already, are we?
Well, maybe I know things you'd enjoy being taught.
Do you think the others know? About us?
Tharan will have guessed, but he knows the value of discretion.
Tharan, but he won't tell.
Good. I like having you all to myself.
Would it bother you if they did?
Does it matter?
No. I just want you all to myself.
Let them gossip. We have nothing to be ashamed of.
I don't care if they know.
Good thinking.
Everything will work out in the end. I know it.
I had a dream. About that ship, where father died. But its corridors went on forever. Father was calling and I couldn't find him.
Everything I've lost; I meditate and study but it still hurts. Shouldn't my training make this better?
"Emotion, yet peace." These feelings will pass; your inner peace cannot be lost unless you allow it.
The Jedi Code says it best.
It's hard to remember when you're crying in the middle of the night.
Your training is intended to help you handle your emotions, not cut you off from them.
Jedi still feel. But we cope.
I thought I'd be all serene and calm by now, that nothing would bother me.
Clinging to what we can never have--or get back--leads only to suffering.
You must learn to let go.
I was so excited about leaving home. Seeing the Republic. Being part of something greater.
Becoming a Jedi's not easy, is it?
Do you have a minute?
I just wanted to mention, you're looking very handsome today.
No more or less than normal, though I appreciate the compliment.
I'm the same as usual.
Don't be so modest.
That sounds even better coming from you.
Thank you, beautiful.
Such praise. You want something?
What are you up to?
Can't a Padawan compliment her Master?
You do so much, but no one ever thanks you. The least you deserve is to be appreciated.
And what do you deserve, for being my comfort and inspiration?
I couldn't do it without you.
I've thought about that.
If that's the least I deserve, perhaps you should keep going.
Then don't stop now.
You're right. Any other Jedi would have been showered with honors by now.
I don't get much recognition.
Maybe I can help you feel better.
Losing father helped me see. We have to do what we can, for the people we care about.
Let's tell everyone we're off training somewhere. We could spend some time alone.
I'd like that... but maybe now isn't the time.
I think we should wait.
Are you doing this because you want to, or because you think you should?
Be sure of your feelings.
I'm... I know what I'm doing.
You have nothing to prove, Nadia.
You don't have to do this.
I'm not some child with a crush. I care about you. Don't you care about me?
You're safe with me, I promise. We don't have to rush into anything.
I care enough to wait.
It's too soon. I'm not going to take advantage of you.
You're still grieving.
I could lose you tomorrow. That's all I can think about sometimes.
At least you didn't say no. I can wait. For a little while.
Caring about someone also means respecting their wishes, Nadia.
Yes, but I said no. For now.
I just don't want to lose you. But I could wait a little longer.
Um. You know that stone I've been practicing my levitation on? I sort of... exploded it.
Did you hurt yourself?
Oh no, I'm fine! Not a scratch.
If focusing on the stone is the problem, focus on the space around the stone instead.
Try a different technique.
You should try levitating our enemies.
That's impressive.
The funny thing is, I managed to hold the stone bits together for a minute or two before it went everywhere. So... progress!
Anyway. If you were wondering about the dust in the access corridor. That's why.
Just so you know, I might not be available for training for a while. An issue's come up back home. It's a real puzzle.
If a challenge has been placed before you, use the opportunity to grow.
Puzzles are lessons, too.
We could talk this over.
I'd like to help you.
Any excuse for some time together.
Perhaps I could help you solve it.
Let's talk about it.
See, a guild back home is building a new spaceport. They want me to petition the Senate for Republic help.
Trouble is, the guild wants to demolish the Annex of Kespan and build the new spaceport on that site.
The Annex is our oldest ruin. To be honest, it's collapsing and sort of dangerous, but... it's sacred.
Is this Annex some sort of temple?
Sacred to whom?
It commemorates Gavail Kespan. He died defending the capital during the Wanderers' Siege.
Surely the guild could build the spaceport somewhere else.
What about an alternate site?
If the Annex is already collapsing, clear it away and do something useful with the land.
I don't see the problem.
But those ruins have been there for centuries.
Clearing another site would take months. The forests around the capital are just too dangerous.
We need that spaceport, but the Annex is so old... what would you do?
A safe port would serve both your people and the Republic. A dangerous ruin serves no one.
Build the spaceport.
"No chaos, only harmony." No more "chaotic" ruins, just harmonious trade. Hopefully.
Spend the credits on renovating those ruins. You'll preserve your heritage, and attract Republic scholars.
You could restore the Annex.
"No ignorance, only knowledge." All right, I'll spread knowledge.
A Padawan needs to trust her instincts. What are they telling you?
Let your intuition guide you.
That I shouldn't let my feelings interfere. We need trade. Maybe the Annex has had its time.
Thank you. You always make me feel better.
Whew! I feel better now. Thanks for talking this over with me.
Dealing with difficult issues is your job now. Do it.
Solve it yourself.
Fine, then. I will.
Oh good, I hoped you'd have some time.
I've been trying to study, but Doctor Cedrax keeps coming to talk to me. He's offering to give me an astronomy lesson.
Apparently he built his own telescope and everything. He's really very charming.
You seem quite taken with our professor.
Do you like him?
Doctor Cedrax? No! He's not my... he's not like you.
Something you have in common. But your company is infinitely preferable.
So are you.
Charming or not, Tharan shouldn't be interrupting while you're trying to work.
Your studies are important.
I like talking to Doctor Cedrax, but only because he's so curious about everything. It's like talking to my father.
It's not a problem, is it? That I'm friends with him?
You can be friends with whomever you like.
Of course not.
I know, but I wanted to ask you. Because... well.
Remember that Holiday's very protective of Tharan and his feelings.
Be careful of Holiday.
I know what that's like. When it... comes to you, anyway.
I'd hate to see him break your heart.
Don't be swept away.
That won't happen.
You're more to me than just my Master. You do know that, don't you?
Doctor Cedrax doesn't come close.
You've known Doctor Cedrax longer than I have. Um, how can I tell him no? Nicely?
Tell Tharan you'd love to spend time with him. Once he's been through the Council's vetting process for potential mates.
Remind him you're a Jedi.
But I don't want--oh! That would work. Still, I'd love to see Doctor Cedrax explaining himself to the Council!
If Tharan's bothering you, Holiday's the best person to put a stop to it.
Tell Holiday. Problem solved.
For a hologram, she's good at keeping Tharan in line. I need to know her secret.
Tharan doesn't understand gentle hints. Be assertive; use your Force abilities if you have to.
Knock some sense into him.
That seems a bit unkind. Though I really want to study in peace.
Thanks for the advice. I'll get caught up on my training, don't worry.
Things are quiet back home, for now. So, I'm going to focus on my Padawan studies.
Um. I read the texts the Council sent me, but I still don't understand what a Padawan does.
A Padawan hones her combat and meditation skills, exercises temperance, and is open to the knowledge of all cultures.
She learns.
So what should I learn first? Master?
All Padawans must first learn humility. So find a mop and bucket, and start with the cargo hold.
She starts by doing chores.
Humility, huh? Then Master Satele told me to tell you: "A Jedi Master needs humility more, so do it yourself and stop teasing your Padawan."
Or we could forget it, and start my first lesson.
Your most important task is to serve and obey me in all things.
She honors her Master.
But what should I know first? To serve you best, I mean.
A Jedi is always patient. The results of your actions may be years, even decades away, and you must be willing to wait.
Patience is most important.
I try, but it's like lighting a fuse. I'm just putting off the bang 'til later.
First: Aggression, hatred and fear can drive even the noblest Jedi to evil. You must always guard against these emotions.
I must warn of the dark side.
But what about the Empire? How can you not hate them for everything they've done?
A Padawan must have complete, unquestioning commitment to her Master, wherever their path may lead.
I demand absolute loyalty.
That wasn't in any of the Council's texts... but I'm not questioning you!
Maybe I should study something else.
Remember the tenets of our order. There is no emotion; there is peace. There is no ignorance; there is knowledge.
Listen to the Jedi Code.
There is no passion; there is serenity. There is no chaos; there is harmony. There is no death; there is the Force.
I should write this down.
Ask the Council for Master Alaqua's "Meditations on a Padawan's Journey." Another perspective might help you.
I can recommend a text.
Consider this. The secret to controlling those beneath you, and those who restrict you, is to know more than they do.
"Knowledge brings control."
I'll give it some thought, Master.
Thank you. I don't mean to be slow. Everything's so new.
You have your studies, and your responsibilities to your planet. Either burden would be heavy enough on its own.
There's a lot on your mind.
Don't you worry, I'll fit everything in.
If you need to talk about anything, I'm always here for you, Nadia.
[Flirt] I'm here to help.
I won't forget.
Your abilities are already exceptional. You just need some theory, and practice.
You're far from "slow."
I want to be a good Padawan. Whatever you can teach me, I want to learn.
Learn to stand on your own feet. I won't always be here to pick you up.
Don't make a habit of it.
I wouldn't ask you to. What's your Padawan beside a galaxy in need?
I was thinking about all the places we've been.
Quesh was fun. Apart from those Imperials all over our research station. And before that was the Fortitude....
The galaxy's just so violent! How do you cope?
As Jedi, we look past momentary chaos and strive for the ideal. In this case, galactic harmony.
By working for peace.
That's very noble.
It must be why you Jedi train so hard. Sorry, I mean, we Jedi!
The Republic has always been a culture of cooperation and innovation. But the war has taken a heavy toll.
It shouldn't be like this.
You sound so sad.
But the Republic's still impressive! Even after all the bombings and Sith attacks and treaties....
Your people aren't pacifists. I've seen your technology.
There's no war on your world?
Well, you have to stand up for yourself. To get the things you want.
I've known you for... how long, now? I thought I had you worked out.
But I think I understand you more, now. And I see you differently.
I'd hate to lose your good opinion.
More favorably, I hope.
No--I like you more! I... I like you.
It's rare for someone to make the effort to understand me.
[Flirt] I'm flattered.
Now I can see the choices you have to make. How hard things must be for you too.
But at least we have each other. A-as allies, I mean.
A Padawan should not speak this way to her Master.
This is inappropriate.
I didn't... I'll remember, Master. It won't happen again.
No, we had wars. But everything's... bigger out here.
Father could never accept the Republic wasn't perfect. He loved the... dream of it.
I wonder how that dream will change. For the better, I hope.
The royal family called the ship. They asked for me, personally.
Can you imagine? They want me to be their new representative.
They obviously don't think I'm as good as father. But I told them my plans, and I'll earn their respect.
Taking this on has clearly been good for you.
You sound much better.
I've cleared my head. And doing father's work has helped too.
It sounds like you've got plans.
What ideas do you have?
I've learned a lot from you, and I'd like a cultural exchange between the Jedi and my people.
I could put these royals in their place.
I'll handle them for you.
No no! Thank you, but I have to do this myself.
I want to use this chance. My people could learn a lot from the Republic--especially from the Jedi.
Jedi training would benefit any Force sensitives on your world.
We could help adepts like you.
Nobody else back home has my powers. I was always... sort of a freak.
When an adult joins the Jedi Order, they don't lose who they were. But they see the path they were walking very differently.
No. You were always a Jedi.
My "path" has a lot of broken dishes and explosions on it.
My opinion may not matter, but I think you're a charming, talented woman.
[Flirt] I like you anyway.
I, um... thank you. And your opinion... matters a lot.
If I was a musician on a world without music, wouldn't they think I was a "freak"?
You just have an unusual gift.
Musicians don't normally make trees explode when they get upset.
With everything that's happened, it shouldn't bother me anymore. But it does.
Maybe doing father's work will be good for me.
Nobody in the order has powers like yours, either. The Council's probably wondering what to make of you.
You're a freak out here, too.
So there's no escape anywhere.
We've never had a chance to talk about where you come from.
Tell me about your world.
It's mostly forest. Cutting road can take years because of all the thorn traps and wild animals.
So our defense technology focuses on protecting our cities. The force fields light everything at night.
I'd... like to show you. I'd feel safe anywhere, if you were with me.
One day I'll go back there. But not yet. There's too much to see.
It seems your people would get the better half of this deal.
We'd get little in return.
We're not asking for charity. We just want to learn. I thought you'd understand.
Sorry, I'm still--everything's so hard.
Home's still burning. All those people. Why couldn't I save them?
Nadia, I grieve for what happened to your world.
I'm so sorry.
I know. But they're still dead, aren't they?
Their sacrifice freed the galaxy from the Children of the Emperor, and the First Son.
They saved the Republic.
I saw our cities burn. Nothing can make up for that.
They're gone, but you're alive. You need to move on, or you'll be no good to anyone.
You have to accept this.
Could you just "move on" if your home went up in flames?
I'm... sorry. You're trying to help. We stepped into a war we knew might not pass us by.
I keep thinking father's going to walk in, and say "Cheer up, Nadia. The sun shines on a smile."
Like I was a child. I hated it. Now I just want to hear it again.
I would have done anything to save him.
I'm very sorry.
It wasn't your fault.
Would it help if you heard that from me?
I could say it.
That's very sweet. But, no thank you.
That's so kind. But it's not the same.
This isn't the time for me to bother you.
I'll leave you in peace.
No, please stay. Please.
I want to stop hurting. I want to be like you. You're so composed.
I just imagine anger or sadness becoming a small, gray pebble. Anyone can cope with a pebble.
I use meditation techniques.
Hmm. I'll give it a try.
You need to come to terms with your grief before you take on new challenges.
Give yourself time.
I should focus on being your Padawan, rather than... anything else.
Holding your emotions until the exact moment you need them can give you great power.
I save my anger for later.
Maybe as your Padawan, I'll understand better.
It's good to see you.
Sorry, no time for training.
Could I talk to you? Just when you have time.
When we get back to the ship, could we talk for a minute?
I sense that... No, you'll have to just tell me.
Is this some part of my training? I don't get it.
You're much more than a Padawan to me.
I feel the same.
I thought so.
I was wondering which of us would be first to say it.
Of course.
You're very kind, Nadia, but--we can't do this. I'm sorry.
This isn't appropriate.
No, no, I understand. I do. Friends, then? Or Padawan and Master--whatever works best.
Come on! Time's wasting, and there's so much to do.
Sure! What do you want me to do?
Yes, master. Whatever you say.
Will do, Jedi. Let's go.
The galaxy's just so violent! How do you cope?
We're in a war; we can't afford to be nice to our enemies.
Everything will work out in the end. I know it.
I was so excited about leaving home. Seeing the Republic. Being part of something greater.
